bibl.title: Letter from Robert E. Lee Michie to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 23, 1900

div1.p: Michie is pleased Kean is doing well and provides him with details of camp life in Havana. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Robert E. Lee Michie to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 23, 1900
div1.opener:
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT
OF HAVANA AND PINAR DEL RIO.
QUEMADOS.
June 23, 1900.
My dear Kean:
div1.p:
Starke has just reported to me that you are doing finely, which
news gives us all great joy. The telegram from Miss Young which
I gave Stark came last night, but the General thought it better
for me to keep it until this morning.

I heard this morning that Stark was sick last night also, and
was just preparing an order detailing myself as Acting Chief
Surgeon when he came in.

We have our little game of hearts as usual at night, but miss
you very much. Last night there were no “sports” present at all,
Jackson being engaged with some thing else. Am glad to headr that
Hepburn is also doing fairly well. He have had your room fumigated
and I think we have caught all the bugs.

Stark tells me that his only trouble was due to some fish
which were a little “off color”, and which fermented a little too
soon.

Brace up old man, and hurry up and come back with us. Let me
know whatever I can do for you. The commissions you gave in your
previous note have all been attended to.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Michie Starke has just returned the cable
for me to send over with this
Rhea joins me in regards.
